error500.title: There’s a problem with this service

content.paragraph1: This is because you did not do anything for more than 2 hours.
content.paragraph2: Go back to the service you were trying to use and start again. You can look for the service using your search engine or find it from the GOV.UK homepage.

moreAbout.paragraph1: GOV.UK One Login is new. At the moment you can only use it with:
moreAbout.listItem1: Apply for a vehicle operator licence
moreAbout.listItem2: Apply to become a registered social worker in England
moreAbout.listItem4: LITE (Licensing for International Trade and Enterprise)
moreAbout.paragraph2: GOV.UK One Login does not work with all government accounts or services yet (for example Government Gateway or Universal Credit).
moreAbout.paragraph3: In the future, you‘ll be able to use your GOV.UK One Login to access all services on GOV.UK.

shareInfo.title: Share information from your GOV.UK One Login
shareInfo.header: Share information from your GOV.UK One Login
shareInfo.bulletPointSectionHeader: This service needs to use your:
shareInfo.paragraph1: You added this information to your GOV.UK One Login when you created it. You can choose to share the information with the service instead of entering it again when you use the service.
shareInfo.paragraph2: The service will only use this information to contact you about the service. It won’t share your information with anyone else. It will keep your information for as long as it needs to or the law requires it to.
shareInfo.paragraph3: If you choose not to share information from your GOV.UK One Login, you may still be asked for that information as you use the service. For example if you choose not to share your email address and phone number and the service needs a way to contact you.

info.paragraph5: Cookies are not used to identify you personally.

accessibilityStatement.title: Accessibility statement for GOV.UK One Login
accessibilityStatement.header: Accessibility statement for GOV.UK One Login

content.paragraph1: GOV.UK One Login is part of the wider GOV.UK website. There’s a separate
content.linkText: accessibility statement for the main GOV.UK website
content.paragraph2: This page only contains information about GOV.UK One Login, available at www.signin.account.gov.uk.

section1.header: Using GOV.UK One Login

paragraph1.text1: GOV.UK One Login is run by the
paragraph1.text2: , part of the Cabinet Office. We want as many people as possible to be able to use GOV.UK One Login. This means you should be able to:

section1.bulletPoint1: change colours, contrast levels and fonts
section1.bulletPoint2: zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
section1.bulletPoint3: navigate most GOV.UK One Login using just a keyboard
section1.bulletPoint4: navigate most of GOV.UK One Login using speech recognition software
section1.bulletPoint5: listen to most of the content in GOV.UK One Login using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)
section1.paragraph2: We’ve also made the text in GOV.UK One Login as simple as possible to understand.
section1.paragraph3: has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.

section2.header: How accessible GOV.UK One Login is
section2.paragraph1: The following parts of GOV.UK One Login are not fully accessible:
section2.bulletPoint1: it’s not possible to stop or change the length of the time-out when you use, sign in to or create a GOV.UK One Login
section2.bulletPoint2: it’s not possible for a screen reader to know when the emails we send are in a language other than English
section2.bulletPoint3: one page reloads automatically after a set time limit, and it’s not possible to stop or delay this
section2.paragraph2: We’ll update this page when issues are fixed or with information about when we plan to fix them.

section3.header: What to do if you have difficulty using GOV.UK One Login
section3.paragraph1: If you have difficulty using GOV.UK One Login,

section4.header: Report accessibility problems with GOV.UK One Login
section4.paragraph1: We’re always looking to improve the accessibility of GOV.UK One Login. If you find any problems not listed on this page or think we’re not meeting accessibility requirements,

section5.paragraph1: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’).
section5.paragraph2: If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint,
section5.linkText: contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS)

section6.header: Technical information about GOV.UK One Login’s accessibility
section6.paragraph1: The Government Digital Service is committed to making GOV.UK One Login accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.

paragraph2.text1: GOV.UK One Login is partially compliant with the
paragraph2.text2: AA standard, due to the non-compliances listed below.

section7.paragraph1: The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons.
section7.subHeader: Non compliance with the accessibility regulations
section7.paragraph2: When you create a GOV.UK One Login or sign in, if you do not do anything for 2 hours, the process will stop (time out) or you’ll be signed out. It’s not possible to adjust, extend or turn off the time out. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.2.1 (Timing Adjustable).

section8.header: What we’re doing to improve accessibility
section8.paragraph1: We’ll update this page when issues are fixed, when we expect them to be fixed or when new problems are identified.

section9.paragraph1: This statement was prepared on 4 November 2020. It was last reviewed on 29 June 2022.
section9.paragraph2: GOV.UK One Login was last tested on 13 June 2022. The test was carried out by the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC), who produced an accessibility audit report on 17 June 2022. DAC assessed GOV.UK One Login against the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines WCAG 2.1.

termsAndConditions.title: GOV.UK One Login terms and conditions
termsAndConditions.header: GOV.UK One Login terms and conditions

paragraph1.text1: These terms and conditions specifically cover GOV.UK One Login. You can use GOV.UK One Login to access and use some government services and features. Pages that are part of GOV.UK One Login have urls containing account.gov.uk. If you are using other parts of GOV.UK you should also read the

paragraph2.text1: GOV.UK One Login is managed by
paragraph2.text2: (GDS) on behalf of the Crown. GDS is part of the Cabinet Office and will be referred to as ‘we’ from now on.

paragraph3.text1: Please read these terms and conditions, the
paragraph3.text3: before using GOV.UK One Login. The privacy notice explains the terms on which we process any personal data we collect from you or that you provide to us. The cookie policy gives information about the cookies we use and how we use them when you use GOV.UK One Login.

section1.paragraph4: By registering for and continuing to use GOV.UK One Login, you agree to these terms and conditions, the privacy notice and cookies policy.
section1.subHeader: Changes to these terms and conditions
section1.paragraph5: We can update these terms, as well as the cookies policy and privacy notice, at any time without notice.
section1.paragraph6: If we change the terms and conditions, we’ll ask you to accept them the next time you sign in to GOV.UK One Login.

section2.paragraph1: You are responsible for making all arrangements for you to access GOV.UK One Login. This includes providing your own device, operating system, browser and internet connection. You should use a device that uses a Windows, OS, iOS or Android operating system. We recommend you use one of the following browsers:
section2.bulletPoint1: The latest version of Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Mozilla Firefox, Samsung Internet or Internet Explorer
section2.paragraph2: We do not guarantee that GOV.UK One Login will always be available, or that access to it will be error free. We will provide a way for you to report problems with GOV.UK One Login.
section2.paragraph3: We may suspend, stop, remove, update or change GOV.UK One Login without notice at any time.

section3.header: Keeping your GOV.UK One Login secure

paragraph1.text1: We have many measures in place to keep your information safe, but as the owner of your GOV.UK One Login, you also have some responsibility for its security. For example you should choose a strong password and ensure you keep it secure. The UK’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) provides

section3.paragraph2: If you think that someone knows the username and password to your GOV.UK One Login, you must reset your password as soon as possible.

section4.paragraph1: You will use your GOV.UK One Login to access government services and for no other purpose.
section4.paragraph2: Unless permitted by law or under these terms and conditions, you must:
section4.bulletPoint1: not copy GOV.UK One Login except where copying is incidental to normal use
section4.bulletPoint2: not rent, lease, sub-license, loan, translate, merge, adapt, vary or modify GOV.UK One Login
section4.bulletPoint3: not combine or incorporate GOV.UK One Login with any other programs or services
section4.bulletPoint4: not disassemble, decompile, reverse-engineer or create derivative works based on any part of GOV.UK One Login
section4.bulletPoint5: comply with all technology control or export laws that apply to the technology used by GOV.UK One Login
section4.paragraph3: You must not use GOV.UK One Login:
section4.bulletPoint6: to transmit any material that is insulting or offensive
section4.bulletPoint7: to collect any data or attempt to decipher any transmissions to or from the servers running GOV.UK One Login
section4.bulletPoint8: in a way that could damage, disable, overburden, impair or compromise our systems or security
section4.bulletPoint9: in a way that interferes with other users
section4.bulletPoint10: in any unlawful or fraudulent manner or for any unlawful or fraudulent purpose
section4.bulletPoint11: in a manner that is improper use or inconsistent with these terms and conditions
section4.bulletPoint12: to gain or attempt to gain unauthorised access to the GOV.UK platform, the server on which the GOV.UK platform is stored or any server, computer or database connected to GOV.UK platform, by hacking or other means
section4.bulletPoint13: to transmit, send or upload any data that contains viruses, Trojan horses, worms, spyware or any other harmful programs designed to adversely affect the operation of computer software or hardware
section4.bulletPoint14: in connection with any kind of denial of service attack or for any malicious purpose
section4.bulletPoint15: with someone else’s registered details, unless you have the authority to do so from them
section4.paragraph4: If you breach any of these terms and conditions, we may stop you from accessing your GOV.UK One Login and may take action to enforce these terms and conditions and take other action as appropriate where we have suffered loss. If, by doing any of the above acts, you are also committing a criminal offence, we may report it to the relevant law enforcement authorities. We may cooperate with those authorities by disclosing your identity to them.

paragraph1.text1: You can permanently delete your GOV.UK One Login and the information in it at any time by signing in or
paragraph1.text2: We’ll keep a record of certain information, in line with our
paragraph1.text3: , for audit purposes and to help prevent crime.

section6.paragraph1: We can make changes and improvements to GOV.UK One Login at any time and without notice to:
section6.bulletPoint2: improve the performance of the service
section6.bulletPoint4: reflect changes to the operating system

section7.paragraph1: You can use GOV.UK One Login to access online government services. These services can be managed by GDS, the Cabinet Office or another government department or agency.
section7.paragraph2: Each service will have their own, separate terms and conditions, privacy notices and cookies policies, which apply to the use of that service. You should read these before you use the service.
section7.paragraph3: If a service run by another government department or agency stops being accessible with GOV.UK One Login the service will contact you to tell you what you should do.

section8.paragraph1: GOV.UK One Login is a tool and we have no liability to you for the online government services that you access using GOV.UK One Login. Liability to you rests with the government service provider.
section8.paragraph2: Although we make reasonable efforts to provide, maintain and update a robust GOV.UK One Login service, it is provided ’as is’. We make no express or implied representations, warranties or guarantees that your access to, or use of, GOV.UK One Login will be unbroken or completely secure.
section8.paragraph3: We will not be liable or responsible for any loss or damage caused by a virus, denial of service attack or any other harmful material that may infect your device, equipment, programs, data or other proprietary material due to your use of GOV.UK One Login.
section8.paragraph4: Nothing in these terms and conditions excludes or limits our liability for:
section8.bulletPoint1: death or personal injury as a result of our negligence
section8.bulletPoint3: any other liability which cannot be excluded or limited under English law
section8.bulletPoint4: loss or damage that may come from using GOV.UK One Login that is not caused by our breach of these terms and conditions
section8.bulletPoint5: loss or damage to a device or digital content belonging to you
section8.bulletPoint6: loss or damage arising from an inability to access or use GOV.UK One Login
section8.bulletPoint7: indirect or subsequent losses that were not foreseeable to both you and us when you started using GOV.UK One Login (loss or damages are ‘foreseeable’ when they are an obvious result of our breach of these terms and conditions or if they were considered by you and us when you began using GOV.UK One Login)
section8.bulletPoint8: loss of profits, revenue, contracts, savings, goodwill and wasted expenditure
section8.paragraph6: GDS is not liable for its failure to comply with the terms and conditions due to circumstances which are beyond GDS’ control.
section8.paragraph7: This does not affect any legal rights you may have as a consumer in relation to faulty services or software. Advice about your legal rights is available from your local Citizen’s Advice or Trading Standards Office.
section8.paragraph8: We are not responsible for any links from GOV.UK One Login to websites that are managed by other government departments and agencies, service providers or other organisations. We do not have any control over the content on these websites.
section8.bulletPoint9: the protection of any information you give to these websites
section8.bulletPoint10: any loss or damage that may come from your use of these websites, or any other websites they link to
section8.paragraph10: You agree to release us from any claims or disputes that may come from using these websites.
section8.paragraph11: You should read all terms and conditions, privacy policies and end user licences that relate to these websites before you use them.

section9.header: Making sure these terms and conditions are followed
section9.paragraph1: Each section within these terms and conditions operates separately. If any provision in these terms and conditions is invalid or unenforceable according to applicable law, we will replace it with a valid and enforceable provision that most closely matches the intent of the original. This includes warranty disclaimers and exclusions, and limits of liability. The rest of these terms and conditions will remain in effect.
section9.paragraph2: If we delay in enforcing these terms and conditions, we can still enforce them later. If we do not insist right away that you follow the requirements within these terms and conditions, or we delay in taking steps against you if you break them, this will not prevent us from taking steps against you or prevent your need to follow the requirements at a later date.

section10.paragraph1: The laws of England apply exclusively to these terms and conditions and to all matters relating to use of GOV.UK One Login. Any cause of action arising under or in connection with these terms and conditions or your use of GOV.UK One Login will be subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the courts of England.

section11.bulletPoint1: questions about these terms and conditions
section11.bulletPoint2: questions or a complaint about GOV.UK One Login

section1.header: Who we are

paragraph1.text1: GOV.UK One Login is provided by the
paragraph1.text2: , part of the Cabinet Office. Mentions of ‘us’ and ‘we’ in this privacy notice refer to GDS.

paragraph2.text1: This privacy notice only covers GOV.UK One Login. Read the main
paragraph2.text2: to find out how your personal information is collected and processed when you use the GOV.UK website.

section1.paragraph3: The Cabinet Office is the data controller of the personal information you provide to us when you:
section1.bulletPoint2: use your GOV.UK One Login to access an online government service
section1.paragraph4: When you provide information to another government service while signed into GOV.UK One Login, the government department that runs the service is the data controller. They will have their own privacy notice to explain how they process your information. We do not have access to the information you provide to services run by other government departments.
section1.paragraph5: When you prove your identity with GOV.UK One Login, we will:
section1.bulletPoint4: ask you for your passport details - we’ll check these with HM Passport Office (HMPO)

bulletPoint5.text4: to make sure you’ve not been a victim of identity theft

section1.bulletPoint6: use Experian’s data to ask you security questions that only you should know the answers to - Experian will also check that your answers match the information they already have about you
section1.paragraph6: HMPO and Experian will also become data controllers during this process. We do not keep any information you give us when proving your identity, including your answers to the security questions.

section2.paragraph1: When you use a service that requires a GOV.UK One Login, we’ll receive information about the service when it directs you to:
section2.bulletPoint1: create a GOV.UK One Login or sign in
section2.paragraph2: The information we collect when you create and use a GOV.UK One Login includes:
section2.bulletPoint3: basic personal information needed to set up and authenticate your GOV.UK One Login, including your email address and mobile phone number, if you choose to get security codes for signing in by text message
section2.bulletPoint4: other information needed to prove your identity, such as your name, date of birth, passport details and address history
section2.bulletPoint5: any information that you choose to save to your GOV.UK One Login, for example your GOV.UK email subscription preferences

bulletPoint6.text1: information on how you use your GOV.UK One Login and the GOV.UK website, which is collected in the system logs, and by Google Analytics cookies if you give consent - the

section2.bulletPoint7: online identifiers, such as your Internet Protocol (IP) address, and technical information about the device you use including the model, web browser and operating system, which is automatically collected in system logs when you use GOV.UK
section2.bulletPoint8: questions, queries or feedback you leave, including your name and email address, if you provide them on the GOV.UK One Login contact form
section2.bulletPoint9: if you were able to prove your identity with your GOV.UK One Login
section2.bulletPoint10: what organisations, services or information we used to prove your identity
section2.paragraph3: When you create a GOV.UK One Login, it will automatically generate a unique identifier.

section3.paragraph1: We collect your personal information to:
section3.bulletPoint1: provide you with a GOV.UK One Login so that you can use it to access online government services

bulletPoint3.text1: store your preferences, for example your

section3.paragraph2: We also use your information to:
section3.bulletPoint4: keep your GOV.UK One Login secure (using your email address, phone number if provided, password and system logs)
section3.bulletPoint6: tell the services you access through your GOV.UK One Login that you have successfully signed in
section3.bulletPoint7: provide government services that you access through your GOV.UK One Login and the departments that run them with information you explicitly agree to us sharing, for example your email and telephone number
section3.bulletPoint8: provide you with a record of how your GOV.UK One Login has been used, for example, when it was last signed in to and what services it has been used with
section3.bulletPoint9: contact you about any planned interruptions, problems or changes that may affect your GOV.UK One Login (using your email address)
section3.bulletPoint10: contact you to ask for feedback on GOV.UK One Login, if you have given us permission to (using your email address)

bulletPoint11.text3: improve and understand how you use your GOV.UK One Login
bulletPoint11.text4: (you can choose not to accept these cookies)

section3.bulletPoint12: respond to any feedback you send us, if you’ve asked us to
section3.paragraph3: We may also use your information to produce anonymised reports about GOV.UK One Login. This helps us understand where we can make improvements to GOV.UK One Login.

section4.header: Our legal basis for processing your information
section4.paragraph1: When we process information for security and fraud monitoring, the legal basis is our legitimate interests.
section4.paragraph2: When we process information to make improvements to GOV.UK One Login, the legal basis is your explicit consent. This includes:
section4.bulletPoint1: collecting and analysing information about how you use your GOV.UK One Login using Google Analytics cookies
section4.bulletPoint2: emailing you to ask for feedback about GOV.UK One Login
section4.paragraph3: The legal basis for processing all other personal data is that it’s necessary in the exercise of our functions as a government department.

section5.header: Who we share your information with
section5.bulletPoint1: sell or rent your information to third parties
section5.bulletPoint2: share your information with third parties for marketing purposes
section5.subHeader1: Sharing your information with online government services and the departments that run them
section5.paragraph2: We’ll tell the services that you access through your GOV.UK One Login when you have successfully created it or signed in, so that they can allow you to use the service.
section5.paragraph3: Services you access through your GOV.UK One Login may ask you to share information you have saved in it. When they do this, we’ll tell you which information they have asked for, and will only share the information if you agree.
section5.paragraph4: If you do not choose to share this information from your GOV.UK One Login, you might be asked to provide the same information directly to the service later on.
section5.paragraph5: Each service you access through your GOV.UK One Login will have its own terms and conditions and privacy notice. You should read these as well as the GOV.UK One Login terms and conditions and this privacy notice, so that you understand how your personal information is managed.
section5.subHeader2: Sharing your information to prove your identity
section5.paragraph6: We’ll share your information with HMPO and Experian when we prove your identity. We’ll only give them the information they need to do this check. They will keep your details for as long as they need to or the law requires them to do so.
section5.subHeader3: Sharing your information to protect against fraud
section5.paragraph7: To protect against crime and fraud, we might sometimes share information with:
section5.bulletPoint3: government departments that run the services you access though your GOV.UK One Login
section5.bulletPoint4: other public sector organisations, such as the Home Office
section5.bulletPoint7: data processors who provide relevant monitoring services
section5.paragraph8: The information we might share includes:
section5.bulletPoint12: information about the devices being used
section5.bulletPoint13: passport details, including name and date of birth
section5.subHeader4: Sharing your information with our suppliers
section5.paragraph9: We work with technology suppliers, for example we use an external hosting provider. These suppliers may have access to your information as part of providing their services to us.

section6.header: How long we keep your information
section6.paragraph1: We store your personal information for as long as is reasonably necessary and legally justifiable.
section6.paragraph2: We will keep your GOV.UK One Login and any information saved in it for as long as you use it. If you delete your GOV.UK One Login or if you don’t sign in for 2 years, we’ll delete all the information associated with it. Any information you delete from your GOV.UK One Login will be permanently deleted.
section6.paragraph3: We will keep your feedback data for 2 years.
section6.paragraph4: We will delete access log data after 365 days.
section6.paragraph5: We will store information about the actions you take and how you use your GOV.UK One Login for 7 years, for fraud monitoring purposes.

section7.paragraph1: GOV.UK One Login is not designed for, or intentionally targeted at, children 13 years of age or younger. We do not intentionally collect or maintain information about anyone under the age of 13.

section8.header: Where your information is processed and stored
section8.paragraph1: All personal data and information associated with your GOV.UK One Login is stored in the UK or in the European Economic Area (EEA). The EEA has been assessed by the Information Commissioner’s Office as having adequate legal protections for data privacy in line with those in the UK.
section8.paragraph2: Where our suppliers require access to your data, they may do so from outside of the EEA. Data collected by Google Analytics may be transferred outside the European Economic Area (EEA) for processing. When either of these things happen, we will make sure your information is just as well protected, for example by including extra clauses in our contracts with suppliers.

section9.header: How we protect your personal information and keep it secure
section9.paragraph1: We are committed to doing all that we can to keep your information secure. We have set up systems and processes to prevent unauthorised access or disclosure of your information - for example, we use varying levels of encryption. We also make sure that any third parties that we deal with keep all personal information they process on our behalf secure.
section9.paragraph2: As the owner of your GOV.UK One Login, you also have some responsibility for its security. For example, you should:

bulletPoint1.text1: choose a strong password and ensure you keep it secure - the UK’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) provides

section9.bulletPoint2: contact us immediately if you suspect that your GOV.UK One Login has been compromised

section10.paragraph1: Your personal information will be subject to automated decision making when:
section10.bulletPoint1: your passport details are checked against data held by HMPO
section10.bulletPoint2: Experian runs an identity fraud check to make sure you’ve not had your identity stolen
section10.bulletPoint3: your answers to security questions are matched against data held by Experian

section11.paragraph1: When you are signed in to GOV.UK One Login you can:
section11.bulletPoint1: access all personal information associated with your GOV.UK One Login
section11.bulletPoint2: change or update your information such as your email address, password and email subscription preferences
section11.bulletPoint3: change your consent to non-essential cookies or tell us how you want us to contact you
section11.bulletPoint4: delete information from your GOV.UK One Login (apart from your email address, password, and mobile phone number, if you do not have another way to authenticate your GOV.UK One Login, because you can’t access your GOV.UK One Login without them)
section11.bulletPoint5: delete your GOV.UK One Login entirely
section11.bulletPoint6: withdraw your consent for your personal information to be processed using web analytics data or feedback
section11.bulletPoint7: object to how your personal information is processed
section11.bulletPoint8: ask that the processing of your personal information is restricted in certain circumstances
section11.bulletPoint9: contact us to get help if you’re not able to prove your identity online

paragraph3.text1: If you have any of these requests, contact the

section12.header: Contact us or make a complaint
section12.paragraph1: Contact the GDS Privacy Team if you:
section12.bulletPoint1: have a question about anything in this privacy notice
section12.bulletPoint2: think that your personal information has been misused or mishandled
section12.bulletPoint3: want to make a ’subject access request’ to find out more about how your personal information is collected and used
section12.paragraph2: You can also contact our Data Protection Officer (DPO) who provides independent advice and monitoring of our use of personal information:
section12.paragraph3: You can also make a complaint to the Information Commissioner, who is an independent regulator.
section12.paragraph4: Making a complaint to the Information Commissioner will not affect your rights.

section13.paragraph1: We may change this privacy policy. In that case, the ‘last updated’ date of this document will also change. Any changes to this privacy policy will apply to you and your information immediately.
section13.paragraph2: If these changes affect how your personal information is processed, GDS will let you know.

password.paragraph2: Do not use a very common password, such as ‘password’ or a sequence of numbers.

securePasswordDetails.summary: How to create a secure password
securePasswordDetails.text: A good way to create a secure and memorable password is to use 3 random words. You can use numbers, symbols and spaces.

section2.paragraph1: We can only respond to your support queries during office hours. Our office hours are 9:30am to 5:30pm, Monday to Friday.
section2.paragraph2: When you get in touch during office hours, we’ll try to reply within 2 working days.

section1.bulletPoint2: suggest improvements or give feedback about your experience using your GOV.UK One Login
section1.paragraph2: Our office hours are 9:30am to 5:30pm, Monday to Friday. We’ll respond to you by email in 2 working days.

secondFactorRadios.authAppText: Authenticator app for smartphone, tablet or computer
secondFactorRadios.errorMessage: Select how you want to get security codes

authAppDetails.paragraph1: An authenticator app creates a security code that helps confirm it’s you when you sign in.
authAppDetails.paragraph2: You can use an authenticator app on your smartphone, tablet or desktop computer.  Download an authenticator app for your smartphone or tablet from your app store or search online for an authenticator app for your computer.

setupAuthenticatorApp.title: Set up an authenticator app
setupAuthenticatorApp.step1: 1. Open your authenticator app on your smartphone, tablet or computer.

noAuthAppDetails.summaryText: I don’t have an authenticator app
noAuthAppDetails.paragraph1: You can download an authenticator app for your smartphone or tablet from your app store.
noAuthAppDetails.paragraph2: If you don’t have a smartphone or tablet, search online for an authenticator app for your computer.
noAuthAppDetails.paragraph3: You can use any authenticator app.

setupAuthenticatorApp.step2: 2. Use your authenticator app to scan the QR code.

cannotScanDetails.summaryText: I cannot scan the QR code
cannotScanDetails.paragraph1: You can enter the secret key into your authenticator app instead.
cannotScanDetails.paragraph3: Some authenticator apps call the secret key a ‘code’.

setupAuthenticatorApp.step3: 3. The authenticator app will show a security code.

code.label: Security code
code.hintText: This is the 6-digit number shown in your authenticator app

validationError.required: Enter the security code shown in your authenticator app
validationError.invalidCode: The security code you entered is not correct, try entering it again or wait for for your authenticator app to give you a new code
validationError.length: Enter the security code using only 6 digits

info.paragraph1: This is because you entered the wrong security code too many times.

signInRetryBlocked.title: You cannot sign in at the moment
signInRetryBlocked.header: You cannot sign in at the moment
signInRetryBlocked.paragraph: This is because you entered the wrong password more than 5 times the last time you tried to sign in. This is to keep your GOV.UK One Login secure.

password.label: Enter a password
password.paragraph2: Do not use a very common password, such as ‘password’ or a sequence of numbers.

validationError.maxLength: Your password must be less than 256 characters
validationError.commonPassword: Enter a stronger password. Do not use very common passwords, such as ‘password’ or a sequence of numbers.
validationError.alphaNumeric: Your password must be at least 8 characters long and must include letters and numbers

validationError.matches: Enter the same password in both fields

securePasswordDetails.summary: How to create a secure password
securePasswordDetails.text: A good way to create a secure and memorable password is to use 3 random words. You can use numbers, symbols and spaces.
